comments.text: He taught you basic manners, the morals clearly went over your head.

comments.text: It's not about commanding respect. You missed the point. It's about SHOWING respect.
comments.author: @ronaldlay6953

comments.text: He missed the lesson entirely!  Wasn’t about control and power, was about humility and respect.
comments.author: @darrellwilliams705

comments.text: "My sister and I..."
comments.author: @andygnatovich

comments.text: This guy read how to win friends and influence people and made a podcast clip about it
comments.author: @jakeatencio305

comments.text: When I was in hospitality I  HATED it when customers used my name. Hated it. Every time.
comments.author: @vlnow

comments.text: The wrong person got rich
comments.author: @duybui3088

comments.text:
_"A person's name is one of their favourite words in the whole wide world!"_ 💯
– Dale Carnegie
comments.author: @YaNeK92

comments.text: Mega respect for the dad to take a backstep and let the son lead. Unfortunately too many parents, specially people born in the 50s and 60s, don't want to lose control ever. That's a great man who knew when to step back and let his son lead while still being present to take of things if it went beyond his son's capabilities. True leader.
comments.author: @Whatreally123

comments.text: Knowing someone's name and using it consciously definitely deepens the connection, however, the other day I was walking my dog and a kid was walking to school through the same park and greeted me with a "Hi Sir! 😊" walking past. I was so surprised by that, since he took the time to pause his phone conversation, though I responded right back at him with a smile and it actually made my day, almost bringing a tear to my eye. All at once it hit me that I'm getting older, made me feel good for being seen but also really proud of him and his parents for raising such a polite young man. I thought if my kids turn out that way one day I'd be pretty happy myself. 💯
comments.author: @YaNeK92

comments.text: this is 100% the best example i've ever seen of someone learning and mastering something they don't understand, this is why the modern world iss in shambles folks, the rich dropped the ball with their kids, none of them know HOW any of it works
comments.author: @intrepidless853

comments.text: He so right.. something I've done for years is try to read the name tag of the bank teller, grocery store register clerk, home depot rep, etc.... when I leave I say : "Thank you Sarah (or whatever) have an amazing day". Try it and watch the reaction you get by calling them by their name... You'll see the power
comments.author: @SignatureRoofing

comments.text: Idk about commanding respect. More like reciprocating respect. You show respect you get respect.
comments.author: @mrchefhayden

comments.text:
Spot on. Always the right approach in any given situation when interacting with others.
Recognition and respect is everything.
comments.author: @minerva1287

comments.text: Totally true. When you make a situation personalized towards the other person, they automatically feel better about themselves and will just naturally treat you with more attentiveness and respect. So just remember to always be polite and respect others and take the time to get to know someone's name. You never know what kind of a difference that could make in some person's day. They could be having the shittiest day of their life and just to know that somebody recognized them by their name and was happy to see them that day could mean the world to them.
comments.author: @ASDsteve

comments.text: Solid work been doing that since I was a boy and it’s a life changer for you and also the people you communicate with. Being present, it’s a lost art.
comments.author: @FELIX-KINCAID

comments.text: I did exactly that this past weekend when i had to do “ make up bday dinner “ for my wife . I kept asking his name and interacted with him and hooked me up with something for wifey. Gave him a hefty tip although i don’t usually do that. I know next time im set but i recognize his job and also been human!!!
comments.author: @Minicupra-m6o

comments.text: It’s recognition acknowledgment and respect , and if you do that you win every single time and you do something good for the people around you.
comments.author: @Ksport31

comments.text: Addressing a person by name personlizes the experience,  it shows a sign of respect that you know there name.
comments.author: @robertmurray8267

comments.text: I once heard, anyone's name, is their favorite word.    It's the MOST beautiful word they have ever heard, using it MAKES them feel good.    Use their name as often as you can, and they might favor you over others (hopefully).
comments.author: @PORTEDLEAF

comments.text: Its called Humility.
comments.author: @Albo96286

comments.text: Kindness is magical!!
comments.author: @lagalaxy9516

comments.text: Barry is speaking truth here. Always important to use their name respectfully and correctly.
comments.author: @jbapples4611

comments.text: If the dad was doing it, he would not have to be told to do it!
comments.author: @TheFrenchMan69

comments.text: I been working in a couple of luxury places in Milan and Forte dei Marmi. I have lot of tattoos (one is a knife on the left side of my head behind my hear) met more than few families like his one, always the best people to deal with and always a pleasure to make their time and experience in the restaurant as good as i can. But is not about commanding respect, is about showing.
comments.author: @SouthEastCoast1312
